No. 21/12)</span></em></span></strong></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 12.0pt; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Police Officers (Special Provisions) Ordinance (</span></strong><span class="midiumtitle"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">LXXXIV OF 1976)</span></strong></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 3</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Bangladesh Public Service Commission (Consultation) Regulation, 1979</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Regulation 6</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">On consideration of section 3 of the Ordinance</span></strong> <strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">vis-a-vis regulation 6 of the Regulations of 1979,</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> it is obvious that consultation with Public Service Commission is mandatory before passing the order of dismissal in respect of each of the respondent as section 3 of the Ordinance of 1976 has not ousted the operation of </span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">other laws, rules and regulations. </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Admittedly,</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> the respondents of both the appeals were Class-II officers. When they were dismissed from service, no consultation was made with Public Service Commission. Because of this inherent defect in the orders of dismissal of both the respondents, we are of the view that the impugned decisions were passed in </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">accordance with law. </span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">Opinion of Public Service</span></strong> <strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Commission is not binding on the authority.</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> The consultation with the Public Service Commission is mandatory before passing the orders of dismissal of both the respondents though the opinion of Public Service Commission is not binding on the authority. ...(22, 23 and 25)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoTitle" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Government of Bangladesh Vs. A.A.M. Salakuzzaman and another (2000) 5 MLR (AD) 281 ref.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">: </span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Mr. Goutam Kumar Roy, Deputy Attorney General, instructed by Mr. Gias Uddin Ahmed, Advocate-on-Record.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;"> </span><span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">: </span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Abdur Rob Chowdhury, Senior Advocate, instructed by Mr. Syed Mahbubur Rahman, Advocate-on-Record.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">:</span> <span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Abdur Rob Chowdhury, Senior Advocate, instructed by Mr. Md. Shamsul Alam, Advocate-on-Record.</span></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">JUDGMENT</span></u></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-variant: small-caps;">Syed Mahmud Hossain, J</span></u></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">: Both the <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">appeals, by leave,  are directed against the decisions</span> dated 26.01.2010 and 04.03.2010 respectively  <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">passed by the Administrative Appellate Tribunal,</span> Dhaka in Appeal Nos.51 of 2005 and 67 of 2008 dismissing the appeals and affirming the decisions dated 10.08.2004 and 23.04.208 respectively passed by the learned Members, Administrative Tribunal No.2, Dhaka and Administrative Tribunal No.1, Dhaka, in Administrative Tribunal Case No. 70 of 2000 (old) renumbered as Administrative Tribunal Case No.141 of 2003 (new) and Administrative Tribunal Case No.45 of 2006 allowing the cases of the petitioner-respondents on contest.    </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">2.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Both the appeals involving similar questions of laws and almost identical facts having been heard together are now disposed of by this single judgment. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">3.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The relevant facts for the purpose of disposal of Civil Appeal No.17 of 2012, in a nutshell, are:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 30.0pt; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">The petitioner-respondent, Md. Billal Hossain Mallik, joined the police department as Sub-Inspector of Police on 10.01.1987. Subsequently, he was promoted to the post of Inspector of Police on 21.12.1993. While he was serving as the Inspector of Police under Khulna Range, the authority pressed a charge sheet against him on 19.07.1999 on the allegation of misconduct. The petitioner-respondent denied the charge and claimed innocence. After that, appellant No.2 passed the impugned order dated 09.09.1999 reducing the petitioner-respondent to the rank of Sub-Inspector of Police under section 5(e) of the Police Officers (Special Provision) Ordinance, <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">1976. Being aggrieved, the petitioner-respondent</span> preferred a departmental appeal on 19.09.1999 and the same was rejected on 26.01.2000. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">4.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Against the order of rejection dated <span style="letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">26.01.2000 passed by the concerned departmental</span> authority, the petitioner-respondent filed Administrative Tribunal Case No. 70 of 2000 (old) renumbered as Administrative Tribunal Case No.141 of 2003 (New) before the learned Member, Administrative Tribunal No.2, Dhaka,</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The respondents-appellants contested the case by filing written objection denying all the material statements made in the application filed before the Administrative Tribunal, contending, inter alia, that on the basis of convincing materials on record, the impugned penalty was rightly awarded to the petitioner-respondent and as such, the impugned order of punishment suffered from no legal infirmity to call for any interference by the Tribunal. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The Administrative Tribunal by its decision dated 10.08.2004 allowed the case of respondent on setting aside the order dated 09.09.1999 reducing the petitioner-respondent to the rank of Sub-Inspector of Police from the rank of Inspector of Police. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Being aggrieved by and dissatisfied with the decision dated 10.08.2004 passed by the learned Member, Administrative Tribunal, Dhaka, the appellants preferred Appeal No.51 of 2005 before the Administrative Appellate Tribunal, Dhaka. The Administrative Appellate Tribunal, upon hearing the parties, by its decision dated 26.01.2010 dismissed the appeal on contest affirming the decision of the Administrative Tribunal.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">The relevant facts for the purpose of disposal of Civil Appeal No.21 of 2012, in a nutshell, are:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 120%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 120%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">         The respondent herein, Md. Tareque Kamal joined Bangladesh Police as Sub-Inspector of Police on 27.03.1990 and subsequently, he was promoted to the post of Inspector for his satisfactory service. While the respondent had been serving as the Officer-in-Charge at Savar Police Station, Dhaka, appellant No.2 herein most illegally placed the respondent under suspension on 11.01.2005 and served a notice upon him for showing cause on 01.12.2005 under the provision of the Police Officers (Special Provisions) Ordinance, 1976 (in short, the Ordinance). In that notice, it has been alleged that the respondent committed offence under section 4(I),(II)(IV)and (VII)of the Ordinance for misconduct, dereliction of duty, corruption and inefficiency. The respondent submitted his reply denying all the allegations under the charge. Appellant No.2 not being satisfied with the written reply of the respondent served provisional order on 09.01.2006 proposing major penalty of dismissal from service. The respondent submitted his reply in time claiming innocence. But appellant No.3 most illegally and arbitrarily passed the final order of dismissal of the respondent from service on 24.01.2006. The respondent preferred an appeal to appellant No.1 on 30.01.2006 but getting no response from the appellate authority, the respondent filed the case before Administrative Tribunal.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">9.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The appellant herein contested the case by filing written objection denying all the material statements made in the application filed before the Administrative Tribunal. Their case, in short, is that the impugned order dismissing the respondent from service was rightly passed and there was no necessity of <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">consultation with the Public Service Commission</span> in awarding punishment to the respondent under the said Ordinance. There was no illegality or irregularity in the proceeding. As such, the case is liable to be dismissed. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">10.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The Administrative Tribunal by its decision dated 23.04.2008 allowed the case of the respondent and directed the appellants to reinstate the respondent in service from the date of his suspension with all attending benefits. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">11.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Being aggrieved by and dissatisfied with the decision dated 23.04.2008 passed by the learned Member, Administrative Tribunal, Dhaka, the appellants   preferred Appeal No.67 of 2008 before the Administrative Appellate Tribunal, Dhaka. The Administrative Appellate Tribunal, upon hearing the parties, by its decision dated 04.03.2010 dismissed the appeal on contest affirming the decision of the Administrative Tribunal. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">12.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Feeling aggrieved by and dissatisfied with the decisions respectively passed by the Administrative Appellate Tribunal, Dhaka, the respondents as the leave-petitioners have filed Civil Petitions for Leave to Appeal Nos. 1433 of 2010 and 1555 of 2010 before this Division and obtained leave respectively in both the civil <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">petitions on 08.01.2012 and 11.12.2011, resulting</span> in Civil Appeal Nos.17 and 21 of 2012.    </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">13.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Goutam Kumar Roy, learned Deputy Attorney General, appearing on behalf of the appellants of both the appeals, submits that the Administrative Appellate Tribunal failed to appreciate that as per section 3 of the Police Officers (Special Provisions) Ordinance, 1976 no consultation is necessary with Public Service Commission (PSC) and as such, the decision of the Administrative Appellate Tribunal affirming the decision of the Administrative Tribunal should be set aside.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">14.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">Mr. Abdur Rob Chowdhury, learned Senior Advocate, appearing on behalf of the respondent of in both the appeals, on the other hand, submits that before imposing major penalty upon a class-I and Class-II Government Officers, the authority must consult the Public Service Commission and as the impugned decision does not call for any interference. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">15.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">We have considered the submissions of the learned Deputy Attorney General for the appellants of both the appeals and the learned Senior Advocate for the respondent of both the appeals, perused the impugned judgment and the materials on record. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">16.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">Before entering into the merit of the appeals, it is necessary to go through the common grounds, for which, leave was granted. The grounds are quoted below: </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">I.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">       </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">Whether both the Administrative Appellate Tribunal and the Administrative Tribunal failed to appreciate that the authority which framed charge against the respondent and eventually awarded the impugned penalty was the controlling authority of the respondent at that time and as such the decision of the Administrative Appellate Tribunal affirming the <span style="letter-spacing: -0.2pt;">decision of Administrative Tribunal</span> is liable to be set aside. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">II.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">Whether both the Administrative Appellate Tribunal and the Administrative Tribunal failed to appreciate that as per section 3 of <span style="letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">the Police Officers (Special Provisions)</span> Ordinance, 1976 no consultation is necessary with the Public Service Commission and as such the decision of the Administrative Appellate Tribunal affirming the decision of the Administrative Tribunal should be set aside.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">17.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">Admittedly, the respondents of both the <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">appeals were dismissed from service by imposing</span> the major penalty on them. The question to be resolved in these appeals is whether before awarding the punishment of dismissal from service consultation with the Public Service Commission is necessary. Admittedly, in both the appeals no consultation was made with the Public Service Commission before awarding punishment of dismissal from service.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">18.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">In order to resolve this issue, it is necessary to go through section 3 of the Police Officers (Special Provisions) Ordinance, 1976. Section 3 runs as follows: </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; line-height: 115%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">“3. This Ordinance shall have effect notwithstanding anything contained in any law, rules and regulations relating to police-force nor shall prejudice the operation of any other law, rules and regulations including the service conditions of the said police-force.”  </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">19.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">Having gone through the section, it appears that this section in no uncertain terms states that the provision of this Ordinance shall have effect notwithstanding enjoying contained in any law, rules and regulations relating to the Police Service but at the same time this section also states that this Ordinance shall not prejudice the operation of any other law, rules and regulations including the service conditions of the said police officers. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">20.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">Regulation 6 of the Bangladesh Public <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Service Commission (Consultation) Regulation,</span> 1979 states that it shall not be necessary to consult the Commission in any disciplinary matter except before passing any order of imposing the penalty of removal, dismissal, compulsory retirement from service, or reduction in rank of a class-I and Class-II Gazetted Officer.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">21.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">Considering regulation 6, it appears that before passing any order of imposing penalty of removal, dismissal, compulsory retirement from service, or reduction in rank of a Class-I and Class-II Gazetted Officer consultation with Public Service Commission is mandatory.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">22.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">On consideration of section 3 of the Ordinance vis-a-vis regulation 6 of the Regulations, it is obvious that consultation with Public Service Commission is mandatory before passing the order of dismissal in respect of each of the respondent as section 3 of the Ordinance has not ousted the operation of other laws, rules and regulations. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">23.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">Admittedly, the respondents of both the appeals were Class-II officers. When they were dismissed from service, no consultation was made with Public Service Commission. Because of this inherent defect in the orders of dismissal of both the respondents, we are of the view that the impugned decisions were passed in accordance with law. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">24.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">In this connection, reliance may be placed</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;"> on the case of <strong><em>Government of Bangladesh vs. A.A.M. Salakuzzaman and another (2000) 5 MLR (AD) 281</em></strong>, in which, it has been held that before imposing major penalty upon Class-I or Class-II Government officer, the authority must consult the Public Service Commission. The opinion of the Public Service Commission is not binding upon the Government which can take contrary view in an appropriate case. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">25.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">Having gone through the case cited above it appears that the consultation with the Public Service Commission is mandatory before passing the orders of dismissal of both the respondents though the opinion of Public Service Commission is not binding on the authority.  </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 115%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">26.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%;">In the light of the finding made before, we do not find substance in these appeals. Accordingly, both the appeals are dismissed.  </span></span></p><p class="Default" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: .5in; line-height: 112%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 112%;">Ed.</span></strong></span></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title=""><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10pt;">CIVIL APPEAL No. 17 of 2012.</span></u></strong></a><u></u></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 3.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 9pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">(From the decision dated 26.01.2010 passed by the Administrative</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 9pt;"> Appellate Tribunal, Dhaka in Appeal No. 51 of 2005)</span></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 3.0pt; text-align: center; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10pt;">With</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10pt; line-height: 110%;">CIVIL APPEAL No. 21 of 2012.</span></u></strong></span></p><p class="Default" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 9pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">(</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 9pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">From the decision dated 04.03.2010 passed by the Administrative</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 9pt;"> Appellate Tribunal, Dhaka in Appeal No. 67 of 2008)</span></span></p></div></div></div></div>
557	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Md. Rabiullah and others Vs. Md. Mostafizur Rahman and others 2017 (2) LNJ (AD) 106</h2>

Mohammad Ali,</p><p><b>Citation:</b>  2017 (2) LNJ (AD) 106</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  2017</p><p><b>Appellant:</b>  Md. Rabiullah and others</p><p><b>Respondent:</b>   Md. <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful List Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false" Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Sections 108(b) and 141</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Order XLI</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Waqf Ordinance (I of 1962)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 43</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Admittedly the appeal was filed before the District Judge under section 43 of the </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Ordinance and in the Ordinance, no procedure</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> has been provided for as to the disposal of </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">an appeal. In view of the provisions of section</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> 141 read with section 108(b) of the Code, the procedure provided therein in Order XLI was applicable in the case of disposal of the appeal in question.                        . . .(8)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Sections 17 and 115(1)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Waqf Ordinance (I of 1962)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Section 43</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The High Court Division did at all advert the finding of the Appellate Court that the order of appointment of respondent Nos.1-3 as the joint mutawallis was obtained from the Administrator of Waqfs by practicing fraud upon him. The High Court Division also failed to consider the age old legal principle that fraud vitiates everything. The High Court Division also failed to consider that in view of the provisions  of section 17 of the Code, the District Judge, Nawabgonj had the jurisdiction to hear the appeal under section 43 of the Ordinance though some of the properties of Waqf Estate were situated in District-Rajshahi.           . . . (11)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Aminul Haque Shah Chowdhury Vs. Abdul Wahab Shah Chowdhury and others, 4 MLR (AD) 367 and Amir Sultan Ali Hyder Vs. Md. K. Alam alias S. Alam and others, 29 DLR (SC) 295 ref.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.2pt;">For the Appellants :</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.2pt;"> Mr. Probir Neogi,</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> Senior Advocate, instructed by Mr.  N.I.  Bhuiyan, Advocate –on- Record. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">For the Respondent Nos. 2-7 :</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;"> Mr. A. J.</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> Mohammad ali, Senior Advocate, instructed by Mr. Taufique Hossain, Advocate -on- Record.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">For Respondent Nos.1 and 8-20 : </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">None represented</span></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">JUDGMENT</span></u></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 10.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Md. Abdul Wahhab Miah,J:</span></u></strong> <span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">This Appeal,</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> by leave, is from the judgment and order dated the 13<sup>th</sup> day of January, 2009 passed by a Single Bench of the High Court Division in Civil Revision No. 4843 of 2000 making the Rule absolute.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">2.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Short facts essential to dispose the appeal are that one late Elahi Box Sarker made a Waqf of some of his properties under the name “Elahi Box Sarker Waqf Estate” (hereinafter referred to as the Waqf Estate) and the Waqf Estate duly registered on 17.10.1321 B.S. As per terms of the Waqf deed, the Waqif became the first Mutawalli of the Waqf Estate. Thereafter Fakir Ullah Miah , son of Nidam Nessa, the first daughter of the Waqif, Sabirullah Shah, son of Chetan Nesa, another daughter of the Waqif and Mostafur Rahman Chowdhury, son of tayabatun Nessa, the youngest daughter of the Waqif, were appointed as Mutawallis in succession. Threafter, the Administrator of Waqfs appointed respondent Nos.1-3 herein as the Joint Mutwallis of the Waqf Estate on 1<sup>st</sup> <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">April, 1998 for the alleged better administration</span> of the Waqf property. The Waqf Estate owns landed properties in Districts, Rajshahi and Nawabgonj. Accordingly, the Administrator of Waqfs directed the Additional Deputy Commissioners (Revenue) of both the Districts to hand over the charge of the properties of the Waqf Estate to the Joint Mutwallis. Being aggrieved by and dissatisfied with the said order of the Administrator of Waqfs, the appellants filed Miscellaneous Appeal No. 40 of 1998 before the District Judge, Nawabgonj. The learned District Judge upon hearing the parties by the judgment and order dated 19 November, 2000 allowed the appeal and set aside the order of the Administrator of Waqfs holding that respondent No.1 obtained the order appointing him and his two brothers (respondents Nos.1-3 herein) as the joint Mutwallis of the Waqf Estate by practicing fraud upon the Administrator of Waqfs inasmuch as he suppressed the fact that the solenama filed on 14.09.1996 in Miscellaneous Appeal No.23 of 1991 was not proved and was not also accepted by the Court and the said appeal  was withdrawn before any order could be passed on the solenama.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">3.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Against this order of the learned District Judge, respondent Nos.1-3 filed the above mentioned civil revision before the High Court Division under section 115(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure (the Code). A single Bench by <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">the impugned judgment and order made the Rule</span> absolute and set aside the judgment and order of the learned District Judge in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 40 of 1998 and thereby the order of the Administrator of Waqfs stood revived.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">4.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">The High Court Division while interfering</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> with the judgment and order of the learned District Judge observed that “For Fair administration of the property in my view there must be common mutawalli”. The High Court Division also observed that the administrator of Waqfs “also did so on 01.04.1998 by appointing the petitioners who were still Mutawalli of the portion of the aforesaid Waqf Estate fallen in the Rajshahi district and as such there should not be different administrators for the other part of the same Waqf Estate. " The High Court Division did not also found the impugned order legal, "because the District Judge, Nawabgonj has not brought in to his consideration that the petitioners are the mutawalli of the Waqf Estate fallen in the Rajshahi district. So. for the benefit of the Administration of the aforesaid Waqf Estate the impugned order should be set aside and the Additional Deputy Commissioner (Rev.), Nawabgonj be directed to hand over the charge of the Waqf Estate fallen in his district to the petitioners who are newly appointed Mutawalli of the entire Waqf Estate by the Waqf' Administrator on 01-04-1998".</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Against the impugned judgment and order, Petition for Leave Appeal No, 490 of 2009 was filed before this Court and leave was granted to consider the additional ground to the effect:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">“the High Court Division fell in error in reversing the judgment and order dated 19.06.2000 passed in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 40 of 1998 being based on findings of fact arrived at by the Appellate Court to the effect that the respondent by practicing fraud and by suppressing the order number 54 dated 04.02.1995 by which the Miscellaneous Appeal No.23 of 1991 was allowed to be withdrawn before accepting the solenama dated 14.06.1996.”</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Probir Neogi, learned Counsel for the appellants having placed the order of the Administrator of Waqfs, judgment and order of the learned District Judge and the impugned judgment and order, has submitted that in view of the provisions of section 17 of the Code , the properties of the Waqf Estate in question having been situated in two different districts, i.e. Nawabgonj and Rajshahi, appeal under section 43 of the Waqfs Ordinance, 1962 (the Ordinance) could be filed before any of the two District Judges, i.e. Nawabgonj and Rajshahi. Therefore, miscellaneous appeal in question was rightly filed in the Court of District Judge, Nawabgonj. Mr. Probir Neogi has further submitted that since no procedure has been provided for in "the "Ordinance for disposal of appeal under section 43 thereof, the provisions of Order XLI of the Code shall be applicable in view of the provisions of section 141 of the Code. But the High Court Division failed to consider the above provisions of law in passing the impugned judgment and order. In support of his contention, he has relied upon the cases of Aminul Haque Shah Chowdhury-Vs-Abdul Wahab Shah Chowdhury and others 4 MLR(AD)367 and Amir Sultan Ali  Hyder-Vs-Md. K. Alam alias S. Alam and others reported in 29 DLR(SC) 295.  He has further submitted that the High Court Division did not at all consider the finding of the Appellate Court that respondent No.l herein obtained the order of joint mutawalliship from the Administrator of Waqfs by practicing fraud suppressing the fact that the solenama dated 14.09.1996 filed in Miscellaneous Appeal No.23 of 1991, was not proved and that before the same could be accepted by the Court, the appeal itself had been withdrawn.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Mr. A. J. Mohammad Ali, learned Counsel,</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> for respondent Nos.2-7, on the other hand, has supported the impugned judgment and order.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Admittedly the appeal was filed before the District Judge under section 43 of the Ordinance and in the Ordinance, no procedure has been provided for as to the disposal of an appeal. In view of the provisions of section 141 read with section 108(b) of the Code, the procedure provided therein in Order XLI was applicable in the case of disposal of the appeal in question. In the context, Mr. Probir Neogi rightly placed reliance upon thecases of Aminul Haque Shah Chowdhury (supra) and Amir Sultan Ali Hyder (supra). And we also find substance in the submission of Mr. Probir Neogi that in view of the provisions of section 17 of the Code, the appeal under section 43 of the Ordinance Could be filed before the District Judge of either of the District, Rajshahi or Nawabgonj. So there was nothing wrong in filing the appeal before the District Judge, <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Nawabgonj against the order of the Administrator</span> of Waqfs by the present appellant and the District Judge rightly decided the same.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">9.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">So far as the merit of the appeal is concerned, from the judgment of the District Judge, it is clear that Miscellaneous Appeal No.23 of 1991 was filed by respondent No.1 against the order of the Administrator of Waqfs dated 16.03.1999 and when that appeal was pending in the Court of the Additional District Judge, respondent No. I as the appellant and two of his brothers who were respondent Nos.8 and 21 filed a solenama on 14.06-1996 with the <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">prayer for disposal of the appeal (Miscellaneous</span> Appeal No. 31 of 1991) in terms of the solenama. The learned Additional District Judge by order No.43 dated 14.09.1996 kept the same with the record and fixed the next date on 28.09.1996 for hearing the appeal along with the solenama. Then upto 09.11.1997 adjournment was taken for hearing the appeal and the solenamaa and lastly the appeal was fixed for hearing on 04.02.1998 and on this date though the appellant and the respondents were present in Court, the appellant filed application for withdrawal of the  appeal and the prayer for withdrawal of the appeal was allowed on that very date, i.e. on 04.02.1998; thus it is clear that the appeal stood withdrawn before the solcnama dated 14.09.1996 could be accepted. But by suppressing the last order of withdrawal of the appeal (Miscellaneous Appeal No.23 of 1991) the order of appointment of the joint mutawalliship was obtained from the Administrator of Waqfs on the basis of the so-called solenama. The Appellate Court gave clear finding that the solenama filed on 14.09.1996 was not proved,  and the same was not accepted by the Court and that subsequently the appeal (Miscellaneous Appeal No.23 of 1991) having been withdrawn, the  solenama filed on 14.09.1996 had no legal consequence and on the basis of the said solenama, respondent Nos.1-3 had no locus standi  to file application on 15.03.1998 and as such, the appointment of the said respondents as the joint mutawallis by the Administrator of Waqfs on 01.04.1998 was obtained by practising fraud upon him; therefore, the order was liable to be set aside.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">10.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Mr. A. J. Mohammad Ali, found it difficult</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> to dispute the above factual aspect of the case.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">11.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In making the Rule absolute, the High Court Division did at all advert the finding of the Appellate Court that the order of appointment of respondent Nos.1-3 as the joint <span style="letter-spacing: -0.2pt;">mutawallis was obtained from the Administrator</span> of Waqfs by practicing fraud upon him. The High Court Division also failed to consider the age old legal principle that fraud vitiates everything. The High Court Division also failed to consider that in view of the provisions  of section 17 of the Code, the District Judge, Nawabgonj had the jurisdiction to hear the appeal under section 43 of the Ordinance though some of the properties Waqf Estate were situated in District-Rajshahi.  In view of the above, the impugned judgment and order cannot be maintained and must be set aside.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">12.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">For the reasons stated hereinbefore, the appeal is allowed. The impugned judgment and order is set aside and those of the District Judge are restored. The Administrator of Waqfs is directed to appoint Mutwalli in respect of the Waqf Estate in question as expeditiously as possible, not beyond 3(three) months from the date of receipt of this judgment, keeping in view the terms of the Waqf deed and the provisions of law notifying the concerned parties and hearing them.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">13.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Office is directed to send a copy of this judgment to the Administrator of Waqfs immediately.</span></span></p><p class="Default" style="text-indent: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN">Ed. </span></strong></span></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="CM12" style="line-height: normal;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title=""><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; font-variant: small-caps;">Civil Appeal No</span></u></strong></a><strong><u><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; font-variant: small-caps;">. 160 of 2010. </span></u></strong></span></p><p class="CM12" style="text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 9pt;">(From the judgment and decree dated the 13<sup>th</sup> day of January, 2009 passed by the High Court Division in Civil Revision No. 4843 of 2000).</span></span></p></div></div></div></div>
558	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Md. Yousuf Ali Vs. University of Dhaka and others 2017 (2) LNJ 223</h2>

Zahirul Huq,</p><p><b>Citation:</b>  2017 (2) LNJ 223</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  2016</p><p><b>Appellant:</b>  Md. Yousuf Ali</p><p><b>Respondent:</b>  University of Dhaka and others </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Writ Jurisdiction</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2017-11-15</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful List Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="60" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException
