font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">After hearing the parties and considering the materials on record, the </span><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Subordinate </span></span><span class="FontStyle26"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-weight: normal;">Judge</span></span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">, First Court, Sirajganj by his judgement and decree dated 19.04.2000 dismissed the suit. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Against the said judgement and decree, the plaintiffs preferred Title Appeal No.29 of 2000 before the District Judge, Sirajganj. On transfer, the appeal was heard by the </span><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Additional District </span></span><span class="FontStyle22"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Judge, </span></span><span class="FontStyle29"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Sirajgonj</span></span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">, who after hearing the parties allowed the appeal reversing the judgement and decree of the trial Court. Then respondent Nos.1 and 2 preferred Civil Revision No.5266 of 2004 before the High Court Division and obtained Rule, which upon hearing the parties was made absolute. Against the said judgement and order of the High Court Division, the plaintiffs filed Civil Petition for <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Leave to Appeal No.2011 of 2009 and leave was</span> granted to consider the</span><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> following submissions of the learned Advocate for the petitioner:</span></span></p><p class="Style3" style="margin: 0in 0in 6pt 0.5in; text-indent: 0.25in; line-height: 110%; text-align: justify;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">“I. That the High Court Division erred in law in interfering with the judgement and decree of the appellate Court without reversing the findings <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">arrived at by the appellate Court in failing</span> <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">to notice that the plaintiffs predecessors</span> being <em>korfa</em> tenants under the landlords, who are in continuous possession in the suit lands, their tenancy matured into title after the acquisition of the rent receiving interest. </span></p><p class="Style3" style="margin: 0in 0in 12pt 0.5in; text-indent: 0.25in; line-height: 110%; text-align: justify;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">II. That there is no material on record to show that the plaintiffs’ predecessors have been evicted from the suit lands by the ex-landlords or that they have surrendered their possession<em>, </em>the High Court Division, in the premises, erred in law in dismissing the suit without reversing the finding of possession arrived at by the appellate Court.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Mahbubey Alam, learned Senior Advocate appearing on behalf of the appellants made submissions in line with the grounds upon which leave was granted. He further submitted that the name of the predecessors of the plaintiffs having been recorded as <em>korfa</em> tenants and there being no materials on record to show that they were evicted from the suit land or they have surrendered their possession, the High Court Division committed an error in dismissing the suit without considering that after acquisition of the rent receiving interest the tenant acquired right in the suit land by operation of law. He further submitted that the trial Court as well as the Appellate Court having found the right and possession of the plaintiffs in the suit land, the High Court Division committed an error in dismissing the suit without reversing the finding of the court below and thus the same is not a proper judgement of reversal. He submitted that the plaintiffs are able to prove their title and possession over the suit land. The trial Court on a technical point dismissed the suit and the appellate Court being the Court of law and fact on elaborate discussion of evidence on record decreed the suit, but the High Court Division without reversing the finding and decision of the appellate Court as contemplated under Order XLI, rule 31 of the Code of Civil Procedure made the Rule absolute and as such the same is liable to be set aside.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Probir Neogi, learned Senior Advocate appearing for respondent Nos.1 and 2 made the following submissions before us:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">“I.  That the appellate Court committed error of law in reversing the  decision  of the  trial Court without adverting  to the fundamental findings of the trial Court to the effect that the defendants having obtained two decrees in respect of the suit property in two  earlier suits,  the  instant suit   was not maintainable without seeking any relief in respect of the said earlier decrees, and as such the judgement and decree of the appellate Court are not sustainable in law, and the High Court Division rightly made the Rule absolute. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">II. That </span><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">the appellate Court being final court of facts committed an error of law, resulting in erroneous decision, occasioning failure of justice in decreeing the suit without considering the evidence on record and without rebutting the findings arrived at by the trial Court on consideration of exhibit '<span style="letter-spacing: 0.3pt;">Kha' of the </span><span style="letter-spacing: 0.3pt;">defendants, the <em>pattan</em></span></span><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: 0.3pt;"> in</span><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> favour </span><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">of their predecessor in the year 1945. </span><em><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Korfa</span></em><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> <em>pattan</em> and the C.S, S.A. and R.S. record, rent receipt and also the decrees declaring the title of the defendants to the suit land, and as such the judgement of the High Court Division in revision making the Rule absolute suffers from no legal infirmity and calls for no interference by this Division. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">III. That the appellate Court committed error of law resulting in erroneous decision occasioning failure of justice in failing to hold that the suit was not maintainable being hit by proviso to section 42 </span><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">of the Specific Relief Act, and the High Court Division rightly made the Rule absolute. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">IV. That</span><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> the appellate Court totally failed to consider the contesting defendants' case and credible evidence led by them. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">V. That the judgement of the appellate Court was against the preponderance of evidence led by the parties, and as such, the High Court Division rightly made the Rule absolute.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">We have considered the submissions of the learned Advocates appearing for the parties concerned, perused the</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> impugned judgement and order of the High Court Division and other connected papers on record.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">9.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">We find from the impugned judgement that the High Court Division reversed the judgement and decree of the appellate Court observing that the finding of fact arrived at by the lower appellate Court is not based on materials and evidence on record. It observed that the appellate Court reversed the finding of the trial Court without any basis. It appears to us that the High Court Division reversed the judgement and decree of the lower appellate Court without giving any specific reasons other than noting that the appellate Court did not reverse the finding of the trial Court.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">10.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">The trial Court observed that the decree in Other Class Suit No.140 of 1974 is not binding of the plaintiffs since they or their predecessor were not party to that suit and similarly in Other Class Suit No.282 of 1976 neither the plaintiffs nor their predecessor were party and hence the decree is not binding upon the plaintiffs. It was further observed that defendant No.1 having claimed that he took <em>pattan</em> of the suit land, could not produce the original <em>amalnama</em> or <em>dakhila</em> and did not give any satisfactory explanation. As a result the claim of defendant Nos.5/6 regarding the alleged <em>pattan</em> is not believable. However, the trial Court then went on to consider that the mutation khatian and rent receipts are evidence to prove their possession. It is noted that the trial Court took into account the submission of the learned Advocate for the plaintiffs that defendant No.5 who deposed as D.W.1 admitted that he was the Nayeb in the Tahsil Office and that the submission of the learned Advocate for the plaintiffs that he had created false and forged <em>pattan</em> and obtained mutation and rent receipts in his name with a view to grab the land, was not without basis. Upon considering the evidence of the witnesses and the materials on record, the trial Court concluded that the plaintiffs are in possession of the suit land and although defendant Nos.5/6 produced mutation khatian and rent receipts, there is good reason to suspect that those are collusive. However, the trial Court dismissed the suit of the plaintiffs on the finding that the <em>korfa</em> title of the plaintiffs’ predecessor subsisted, but they were unable to produce any evidence to prove such title. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">11.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">We find from the judgement of the appellate Court that it was observed that the decree in Other Class Suit No.140 of 1974 was not binding on the plaintiffs since neither they nor their predecessor (mourash) were party in that suit. It was further noted that in this regard the learned Advocate on behalf of the defendants was not able to give any satisfactory explanation.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">12.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">                   </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">The appellate Court concluded as follows:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Courier New';">“</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">The appellate Court observed that during <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">the pendency of the appeal, the plaintiffs produced </span>certified copy of C.S. khatian No.21 and the original porcha of the khatian Nos.22-29 and 31 as well as the certified copy of khatian No.30, which were marked as exhibit-4 series and admitted into evidence without objection. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt The appellate Court as the last court of fact found that the claim of <em>pattan</em> as made by defendant Nos.5/6 was not believable.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">16.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The appellate Court concluded that since there was nothing to suggest that the <em>korfa</em> title of the plaintiffs’ predecessor had been lost, it is reasonable to conclude that the tenancy in the land has devolved upon the plaintiffs. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">17.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">We also note that sub-khatian Nos.22 to 31 of khatian No.21 record the name of the plaintiffs’ predecessor Adam Pramanik as <em>korfa</em> tenant since 1922. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt -4.5pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">18.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">           </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In view of the above discussion, we find that the appellate Court as the last court of facts has meticulously discussed the evidence on record and rightly reversed the findings of the trial Court. The observation of the High Court Division that the appellate Court did not reverse the findings of the trial Court is not correct. The appellate Court has elaborately dealt with the points raised by the trial Court. Moreover, we find that the conclusion of the trial Court is not consistent with the findings and observations made by it. Accordingly, the impugned judgement and order of the High Court Division is not sustainable. Hence, the appeal is allowed, without however, any order as to costs.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 10.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">         </span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The impugned judgement and order of the High Court Division is set aside.</span></span></p><p class="Default" style="text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: windowtext;">Ed. </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> </span></strong></span></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title=""><strong><u><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; font-variant: small-caps;">Civil  Appeal  No. 92 of 2010</span></u></strong></a><u></u></span></p><p class="CM12" style="text-align: justify; line-height: normal;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 9pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">(From the judgement and order dated 16<sup>th</sup> of August, 2009 passed by the High Court Division in Civil Revision No. 5266 of 2004.)</span></p></div></div></div></div>

105%;">Mosammat Rupia Aktar and another </span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 105%; margin: 0in -1.45pt 3.0pt -1.0pt;"><span Pre-emptor-Opposite party-Petitioners </span></em></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 105%; margin: 0in -1.45pt 3.0pt -1.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">-Versus-</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: -.7pt; tab-stops: 15.95pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Md.</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> Ayet Ali and others </span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: -7.0pt; text-align: right;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">... Pre-emptee-Petitioner-Opposite parties</span></em></strong></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">State Acquisition and Tenancy Act (XXVIII of 1951)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 96</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">At the time of filing of the case for the Pre-Emption under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 as amended by Act 34 of 2006 having come into force on 20.09.2006, only co-sharer by inheritance has <em>locustandi </em>to prefer pre-</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">emption Miscellaneous Case. As the petitioner</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> referred as pre-emptor was co-sharer by purchase (stranger) in the case jote, he is not entitled to have the land pre-empted by preferring Pre-Emption miscellaneous case under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951.       . . . (13, 14 and 17)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 151</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 105%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">Inherent jurisdiction of the court to prevent the abuse of the process of the court is very much applicable in each and every case; where it is found that the proceeding which is pending before a court of law is a futile effort and its ultimate result is zero the Court by exercising the inherent power can prevent the abuse of the process of the Court.                                                . . .(18)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">18 DLR 709, 716 and 13 BLD (AD) 56 ref.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 2.9pt .0001pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Md.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Ashraful Alam, Advocate</span></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 2.9pt 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">. . . <strong><em>For the petitioners.</em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 2.9pt .0001pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Md.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Rafiqul Islam, Advocate</span></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 2.9pt 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">. . . For the opposite parties</span></em></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 150%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 150%;">JUDGMENT</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Soumendra Sarker, J:</span></u></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> The Rule was issued calling upon the Opposite Party No.1 to show cause as to why the judgment and order dated 06.03.2011 passed by the learned Judge, Jananirapatta Bighnakari Aparadh Daman Tribunal, Comilla in Civil Revision No.06 of 2011 (59/2010) reversing the order dated 09.06.2010 passed by the learned Senior Assistant Judge, Sadar, Comilla in Pre-emption Miscellaneous Case No.579 of 2008 should not be set aside and/or pass such other or further order or orders as to this Court may seem fit and proper.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">2.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The facts leading to the issuance of the Rule in a nutshell can be stated thus, that the present petitioners as pre-emptors filed a pre-emption miscellaneous case under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 in the Court of learned Senior Assistant Judge, Sadar, Comilla against the Pre-emptee-Opposite party No.1 and others contending inter alia that the case <em>jote</em> is the <em>ejmali</em> homestead wherein the petitioner and other co-sharers are residing with their family members. The opposite party No.2 transferred the case land in favour of the pre-emptee without serving any notice and without any information to the petitioners. For getting the land pre-empted the pre-emptors filed the pre-emption miscellaneous case within time. The further case of the pre-emptors is such that the <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">purchaser-pre-emptee is a stranger to the case <em>jote</em>.</span></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">3.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The contrary case of the pre-emptee-opposite party in short is such that the case is barred by law as it is not maintainable and the pre-emptors on false allegation filed the case.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">4.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">During pendency of the case the pre-emptee after making his appearance filed a written objection alleging that under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 under which the pre-emptors have instituted the original pre-emption miscellaneous case is not maintainable and that is why the pre-emption miscellaneous application is liable to be rejected under Order VII Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure along with other grounds cited therein. The learned trial Judge vide his order dated 24.05.2010 rejected the application for rejection of the pre-emption miscellaneous petition under Order VII Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure and thereafter, by an order dated 09.06.2010 opined that the pre-emption miscellaneous case is maintainable in its present form.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Being aggrieved the pre-emptee preferred</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> a revisional application in the court of learned District Judge, Comilla being No.06 of 2011 (59/2010) which was transmitted to the learned judge (District Judge) Jananirapatta Bighnakari Aparadh Daman Tribunal, for hearing and disposal and the learned Judge (District Judge), Jananirapatta Bighnakari Aparadh Daman Tribunal and Special District Judge, Comilla by the impugned judgment and order dated 06.03.2011 allowed the revisional application and set aside the orders of the learned trial Judge. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Being aggrieved by and dissatisfied with the impugned judgment and order of the 1<sup>st</sup> revisional Court the pre-emptor-petitioners with leave of this Court have preferred a 2<sup>nd</sup> revisional application under section 115(4) of the Code of Civil Procedure and obtained the Rule.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 2.9pt 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">During hearing of this Rule Mr. Md. Ashraful Alam, the leaned Advocate appeared on behalf of the petitioners while Mr. Md. Rafiqul Islam the learned Advocate appeared on behalf of the opposite parties.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The learned Advocate appearing on behalf of the petitioners submits that the learned trial court during passing the orders dated 24.05.2010 and 09.06.2010 committed no illegality; but the learned 1<sup>st</sup> revisional court illegally allowed the revisional application without proper appreciation of law and facts of the case. The learned Advocate further submits that the orders of the learned trial court was appealable but the learned District Judge entertaining the revisional application committed an error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice. The learned Advocate lastly submits that the Special District Judge, Comilla was without jurisdiction in passing the impugned judgment and order and as such the Rule is liable to be made absolute.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">9.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">As against the aforesaid submissions of the learned counsel for the petitioners the learned Advocate appearing on behalf of the opposite parties opposing the Rule controverted the grounds of the revisional application and the argument advanced from the side of the learned Advocate for the petitioners and submits that the learned 1<sup>st</sup> revisional court was quite empowered to entertain the revisional application and committed no error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice. The learned Advocate further submits that in fact; the original pre-emption miscellaneous case was not maintainable under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 and the pre-emptors had no right to institute the original pre-emption miscellaneous case under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act inasmuch as admittedly they were not the co-sharers by inheritance in the case <em>jote</em> and the learned 1<sup>st</sup> revisional court after proper appreciation of the connected law apprised that the matter is to be decided under the purview of law which is prevailing at present and as it is found that, the petitioners have no <em>locus standi</em> to file such application for pre-emption. The learned trial court had no other alternative but to dismiss the original case. The learned Advocate also submits that the case kabalas admittedly were executed on 07.07.2008 and 26.12.2007 and both the two cases for pre-emption were filed on 30.12.2008 which is long after the amendment of Section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951. Thereafter; the Purchaser-Pre-emptee-Opposite party knowing about the institution of the original cases filed the application under Order VII Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure for rejection of plaint, but while the learned trial court illegally disallowed the said application for rejection of plaint the learned District –Judge entertaining the Civil Revision set-aside the orders of the trial court forthwith for ends of justice. The learned Advocate lastly submits that both the two cases were barred by law and thereby the learned 1<sup>st</sup> revisional court was quite legal and justified in holding the view that the cases are liable  to be dismissed.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">10.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">I have heard the submissions of the learned Advocates of both sides and have gone through the impugned judgment and order along with the connected papers.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">11.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">On perusal of the connected papers it transpires that the present petitioners for having the case land pre-empted filed the pre-emption miscellaneous case under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 against the pre-emptee on 30.12.2008. It is the specific case of the pre-emptors that they are the co-sharers by purchase in the case holding and by virtue of that capacity they have filed the pre-emption miscellaneous cases against the stranger purchaser-pre-emptee. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">12.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">It further appears that in fact the learned District Judge Comilla entertained the Civil Revision against an order on maintainability of the original case; which was a revisonal order and not appealable.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">13.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Having gone through the case records it further transpires that the case kabalas were executed on 07.07.2008 and 26.12.2007. The learned 1<sup>st</sup> revisional court during disposal of the revisional application held that, after institution of the original miscellaneous case the pre-emptee challenging the <em>locus standi</em> of the pre-emptors filed an application for rejection of plaint under Order VII rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure. In the said application it was cited by the pre-emptee that the pre-emptors have claimed themselves the co-sharers by purchase in the case <em>jote;</em> but save and except the co-sharers by inheritance nobody is entitled to have the land pre-empted <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">under the amended provision of Pre-emption law.</span></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">14.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">On meticulous Consideration of the papers I find that the learned 1<sup>st</sup> revisional court <em>i.e.</em> the learned Judge(District Judge), Jananirapatta Bighnakari Aparadh Daman Tribunal, Comilla rightly held that at the time of filing of the cases for the Pre-Emption   under the provision of relevant law only the co-sharer by inheritance have <em>locustandi</em> to prefer pre-emption miscellaneous case under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">15.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">It is a fact; that the law of pre-emption incorporated in section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1951 has been amended and it has come into effect from 20.09.2006.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">16.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The law of pre-emption under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act has been amended by Act XXXIV of 2006. The former section 96, after  has been amended by the act of law and the right of pre-emption under the said section 96 after the above mentioned amendment runs as follows:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">   “96. Right of Pre-emption-(1) If a portion or share of a holding of a raiyat is sold to a person who is not a co-sharer tenant in the holding, one or more co-sharer tenants of the holding may, within two months of the service of the notice given under section 89, or, if no notice has been served under section 89, within two months of the date of the knowledge of the sale, apply to the Court for the said portion or share to be sold to himself or themselves:</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Provided that no application under this section shall lie unless the applicant is- </span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(a) a co-sharer tenant in the holding by inheritance; and</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(b) a person to whom sale of the holding or the portion or share thereof, as the case may be, can be made under section 90:</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Provided further that no application under this section shall lie after expiry of three years from the date of registration of the sale deed.”</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">17.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Having regard to the cited provision of law obviously it is noticed that the learned <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Special Judge, Comilla appreciating the position</span> of law decided the merit of the revisional application and inasmuch as it has become clear that excepting the co-sharer by inheritance the person having other status who is other than co-sharer by inheritance is not in a position to qualify himself for institution of pre-emption case.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">18.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">I find that, keeping ahead the submissions</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> advanced form the side of the learned Advocates for the parties the learned 1<sup>st</sup> revisional court relying upon some decisions of this Court reported in 18 DLR 709 and 716 invoking the inherent power of the Court and 8 BLC 144 with regard to applicability of section 141 of the Code of Civil Procedure in the proceeding under section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act and 13 BLD (AD)56 decided the merit of the revisional application in the affirmative rightly</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">19.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In this context; the decisions referred to from the sides of the learned counsels of the parties to the case go to show that it is a decided matter that the inherent jurisdiction of the court to prevent the abuse of the process of the court is very much applicable in each and every case; where it is found that the proceedings which is pending before a court of law is a futile effort and its ultimate result is zero. The fact remains that in the instant case as I have come across that the learned 1<sup>st</sup> revisional court rightly and legally held in consultation with the relevant papers that in case of further proceedings of the original cases there would be mere abuse of the process of the court and as such the learned trial court ought to have dismissed the case pending therein under his inherent power of section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">20.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Having regard to the facts, circumstances and discussions referred to above I have every reason to inclined such a view that the learned District Judge committed no wrong or pre-judicial act in holding the view that the original case for getting the case land pre-empted is not maintainable and as it is barred by law and for that reason the same is liable to be dismissed on the ground of maintainability instantly without any further delay, to prevent abuse of the process of the court  and as such the Rule have got no merit to succeed.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">21.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">In the result, the Rule is discharged without any order as to costs. The judgment and order dated 06.03.2011 passed by the learned Judge (District Judge), Jananirapatta Bighnakari Aparadh Daman Tribunal, Comilla in Civil Revision No.06 of 2011 (59 /2010) reversing the order dated 09.06.2010 passed by the learned Assistant Judge, Sadar, Comilla in Pre-emption Miscellaneous Case No.579 of 2008 is hereby affirmed. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level3 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">22.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">                   </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">Communicate the judgment and order at once.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Ed. </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> </span></strong></span></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title=""><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10pt; line-height: 110%;">Civil Revision No. 1549 of 2011</span></strong></a></span></p></div></div></div></div>
561	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Mosammat Rupia Aktar and another Vs. Md. Ayet Ali and others 2017 (2) LNJ 219</h2>

J.</p><p><b>Court:</b> High Court Division,</p><p><b>Advocate:</b> Mr. Md. Ashraful Alam, Mr. Md. Rafiqul Islam,</p><p><b>Citation:</b>  2017 (2) LNJ 219</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  2017</p><p><b>Appellant:</b>  Mosammat Rupia Aktar and another</p><p><b>Respondent:</b>  Md. Ayet Ali and others </p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Civil Law</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2017-11-15</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View>
